title: Twitter misses Wall Street's revenue predictions by nearly £40m
text:
Twitter missed Wall Street's revenue predictions by nearly £40million after its advertising business suffered from technical 'bugs'.

The social media company reported sales of about £638million for the three months to September 30, up from £587million during the same period last year.

However, it was below the £677million predicted by analysts and shares tumbled 20 per cent.

Bosses said this was partly because of glitches that affected the technology behind its advertising services and partly because of unusually-low demand over the summer, when fewer big events had taken place compared to the previous year.

Ned Segal, Twitter's chief financial officer, said the bugs 'affected our ability to target ads and share data with partners'.

He added: 'Despite its challenges, this quarter validates our strategy of investing to drive long-term growth.'

But the problems triggered a slump in shares, with the company warning they were likely to affect the fourth quarter as well.

Tesla back in the fast lane Tesla shares shot up after it unexpectedly returned to the black. The electric car maker's stock surged by as much as 20 per cent when trading in the US opened, hours after it stunned Wall Street with a £111million third quarter profit. It was only the fifth quarter in Tesla's 16-year history that it has avoided a loss. It notched up losses of £855million in the first half of 2019. Daniel Ives, an analyst at Wedbush Securities, described the profit as a 'jaw dropper'.

Before the announcement, Twitter had been valued at about £23billion but the early drop saw more than £4billion wiped off that figure.

Despite the turmoil, Jack Dorsey, Twitter's co-founder and chief executive, insisted the company was in 'its strongest position ever'.

'We're much better equipped to identify and fix issues we come across today than we were just one to two years ago,' he told analysts, adding such problems were 'still painful but no longer existential'.

Twitter said 145million daily active users saw its ads, better than an expected 141million.

But the company told investors it was expecting fourth quarter revenues of between £728million and £782million, well below Wall Street predictions of about £821million.

Ben Marder, associate professor of marketing at Edinburgh University's Business School, warned the company would also be tested in the coming months ahead of the 2020 US elections.

He warned that so-called 'deepfakes' – realistic-looking videos showing someone saying or doing something that they did not actually do – had the potential to 'cause havoc'.
